item.text:
Steve Gleason Enduring Voices Act of 2017

This bill amends title XVIII (Medicare) of the Social Security Act to make permanent the elimination of a specified payment cap under the Medicare program with respect to speech generating devices.
item.name: Introduced in House

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Referred to House Ways and Means
Referred to House Energy and Commerce

Referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

item.title: Steve Gleason Enduring Voices Act of 2017
item.titleType: (Extracted from GPO) Short Titles as Introduced

item.title: Steve Gleason Enduring Voices Act of 2017
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to make permanent the removal of the rental cap for durable medical equipment under the Medicare program with respect to speech generating devices.
Steve Gleason Enduring Voices Act of 2017

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

bill.title: Steve Gleason Enduring Voices Act of 2017
bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mrs. McMORRIS RODGERS:H.R. 2465.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The power of the Congress to regulate Commerce asenumerated by Article I, Section 8, Clause 3 as applied tothe Social Security Act.[Page H4224]

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
